translated: Even though correctly stated in the ultimate sense, it is a fallacious example because of the fault of the speaker.

analyzed: parārtha anumāne vaktuḥ guṇa doṣayoḥ dvayoḥ vicāraṇīya tvāt
translated: Because in an inference for another, the qualities and faults of the speaker are to be considered as two.

original: evaṃ yannityaṃ tatsarvaṃ niyatamakṛtakaṃ dṛśyate yathākāśādiriti vāgvibhāgo vaktrā karttavyaḥ /🔽pūrvavarttino vyatirekasyāpradarśanādapradarśitavyatirekaḥ //
analyzed: evam yat nityam tat sarvam niyatam akṛtakam dṛśyate yathā ākāśa ādiḥ iti vāc vibhāgaḥ vaktrā karttavyaḥ  pūrva varttinaḥ vyatirekasya apradarśanāt apradarśita vyatirekaḥ
translated: Thus, the speaker should make the distinction in speech: Whatever is permanent, all that is necessarily seen to be unproduced, like space and so on.

analyzed: viparīta vyatirekaḥ yathā
translated: The one with opposite exclusion is like this.

analyzed: yat akṛtakam tat nityam dṛṣṭam iti
translated: What is not produced is seen to be eternal.

analyzed: iha tu sādhya viparīte vyāptiḥ darśanīyā
translated: Here, the pervasion should be shown in the opposite of the probandum.

analyzed: tena yat yat sādhya viparītam tat tat niyatam sādhana viparītam bhavet
translated: Therefore, whatever is opposite to the probandum must be opposite to the probans.

original: aṣṭādaśa dṛṣṭāntābhāsā uktāḥ //🔽ebhireva pakṣahetudṛṣṭāntābhāsairvādinā sādhanasyāvyutpatteḥ prativādī dūṣaṇamupanyasyati /
analyzed: aṣṭādaśa dṛṣṭānta ābhāsāḥ uktāḥ  ebhiḥ eva pakṣa hetu dṛṣṭānta ābhāsaiḥ vādinā sādhanasya avyutpatteḥ prativādī dūṣaṇam upanyasyati
translated: Eighteen fallacious examples have been stated.🔽The opponent presents a refutation by the fallacies of the thesis, reason, and example themselves, because the proponent has not established the proof.

analyzed: tasya dūṣaṇasya pūrvapakṣa vādinaḥ bhīṣṭa artha siddhau pratibandhaka tvāt sādhana nyūna tā udbhāvanam eva dūṣaṇam ucyate
translated: Since that refutation obstructs the establishment of the desired meaning of the proponent of the prima facie view, it is said to be merely pointing out the deficiency of the proof.

analyzed: tasmāt sādhanavat dūṣaṇa lakṣaṇa vibhagāḥ pṛthak na uktaḥ
translated: Therefore, the characteristics and divisions of refutation are not stated separately, like the proof.

analyzed: dūṣaṇa ābhāsaḥ dūṣaṇam eva iti sa prativādinā ucyate
translated: A fallacious refutation is said to be a refutation by the opponent.

original: yadā pūrvapakṣavādino 'bhūtaṃ doṣamudbhāvayati tadā sa dūṣaṇābhāso jātiriti /
analyzed: yadā pūrvapakṣa vādinaḥ bhūtam doṣam udbhāvayati tadā sa dūṣaṇa ābhāsaḥ jātiḥ iti
translated: When the proponent of the prima facie view presents a false fault, then that fallacious refutation is called a jāti.

analyzed: abhūta doṣa udbhāvanam viparīta uttaram jātiḥ iti ucyate
translated: The presentation of a false fault is called a jāti, a fallacious rejoinder.

original: yathā pakṣadoṣābhāve pakṣadoṣodbhāvanaṃ hetudoṣābhāve hetudoṣodbhāvanaṃ dṛṣṭāntadoṣābhāve ca dṛṣṭāntadoṣodbhāvanaṃ dūṣaṇābhāsa iti //
analyzed: yathā pakṣa doṣa abhāve pakṣa doṣa udbhāvanam hetu doṣa abhāve hetu doṣa udbhāvanam dṛṣṭānta doṣa abhāve ca dṛṣṭānta doṣa udbhāvanam dūṣaṇa ābhāse iti
translated: Just as the statement of a fallacy of the example is a fallacy of refutation when there is no fallacy of the example, similarly the statement of a fallacy of the reason is a fallacy of refutation when there is no fallacy of the reason, and the statement of a fallacy of the subject is a fallacy of refutation when there is no fallacy of the subject.

analyzed: tatra āhuḥ anye
translated: Regarding this, others say:

original: pratijñā hetuḥ udāharaṇam upanayaḥ nigamanaṃ ceti pañcāvayavaṃ sādhanamiti /
analyzed: pratijñā hetuḥ udāharaṇam upanayaḥ nigamanam ca iti pañca avayavam sādhanam iti
translated: The proof has five parts: the thesis, the reason, the example, the application, and the conclusion.

analyzed: yathā anityaḥ śabdaḥ iti pratijñā
translated: For example, Sound is impermanent is the thesis.

analyzed: kṛtaka tvāt iti hetuḥ
translated: Because it is produced is the reason.

original: yatkṛtakaṃ sarvaṃ tadanityaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ yathā ghaṭādirityudāharaṇam /
analyzed: yat kṛtakam sarvam tat anityam dṛṣṭam yathā ghaṭa ādiḥ iti udāharaṇam
translated: Whatever is produced is seen to be impermanent, like a pot, etc. is the example.

analyzed: tathā śabdaḥ api kṛtakaḥ iti upanayaḥ
translated: Sound is also produced in the same way is the application.

analyzed: tasmāt anityaḥ iti nigamanam
translated: Therefore, it is impermanent is the conclusion.

analyzed: dṛṣṭānta pratīta sāmarthyasya hetoḥ dharmiṇī upasaṃhāraḥ upanayaḥ iti
translated: The application is the bringing together of the reason, whose capacity has been understood from the example, to the subject.

analyzed: pratijñāyā punar śravaṇam nigamanam iti ucyate
translated: The repetition of the thesis is called the conclusion.

analyzed: mā evam anvayaḥ vyatirekaḥ pakṣa dharmaḥ ca iti trayeṇa eva sādhya artha siddheḥ
translated: This is not so, because the probandum is established by the three alone: the positive concomitance, the negative concomitance, and the property of the subject.

analyzed: evam vāda kāle vyāpti pūrvakaḥ eva prayogaḥ
translated: Thus, at the time of debate, the use of the reason must be preceded by the statement of the pervasion.

original: yatkṛtakaṃ sarvaṃ tadanityaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ yathā ghaṭādiriti dṛṣṭānte sādhyasādhanayorvyāptipratipādanamanvaya ityucyate //
analyzed: yat kṛtakam sarvam tat anityam dṛṣṭam yathā ghaṭa ādiḥ iti dṛṣṭānte sādhya sādhanayoḥ vyāpti pratipādanam anvayaḥ iti ucyate
translated: That which is produced is seen to be impermanent, like a pot etc. The pervasion of the thesis and reason in the example is called concomitance.

analyzed: vipakṣe punar sādhya vyāvṛttyā sādhana vyāvṛttiḥ vyatirekaḥ iti ucyate
translated: In the case of the counter-example, the exclusion of the reason by the exclusion of the probandum is called the counter-concomitance.

analyzed: yathā anitya tva abhāve kṛtaka tva abhāvaḥ syāt yathā ākāśa ādiḥ
translated: For example, in the absence of impermanence, there would be absence of being produced, like in space etc.

analyzed: śabdaḥ api kṛtakaḥ iti pakṣa dharmaḥ ucyate
translated: Sound is also produced - this is stated as the property of the subject.

original: pratijñā nigamanaṃ ca sarvathā na vaktavye //
analyzed: pratijñā nigamanam ca sarvathā na vaktavye
translated: The proposition and the conclusion should not be stated at all.

analyzed: tathā sādharmya prayoge nvaya vacana sāmarthyāt vyatireka avagamāt ayam pṛthak nā ucyate
translated: Similarly, in the case of the affirmative method, the counter-concomitance is understood by the force of the statement of concomitance, so it is not stated separately.

original: yathā yatkṛtakaṃ sarvaṃ tadanityaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ yathā ghaṭādiḥ śabdo 'pi kṛtaka iti sādharmyaprayogaḥ /
analyzed: yathā yat kṛtakam sarvam tat anityam dṛṣṭam yathā ghaṭa ādiḥ śabdaḥ api kṛtakaḥ iti sādharmya prayogaḥ
translated: For example, Whatever is produced is seen to be impermanent, like a pot etc. Sound is also produced - this is the affirmative method.

analyzed: vaidharmya prayoge vyatireka vacana sāmarthyāt anvaya pratītiḥ
translated: In the negative method, the concomitance is understood by the force of the statement of counter-concomitance.

analyzed: atra punar anvayaḥ na vācyaḥ
translated: Here, the concomitance should not be stated.

original: yannityaṃ tadakṛtakaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ yathākāśādiḥ śabdastu kṛtaka iti vaidharmyaprayogaḥ //
analyzed: yat nityam tat akṛtakam dṛṣṭam yathā ākāśa ādiḥ śabdaḥ tu kṛtakaḥ iti vaidharmya prayogaḥ
translated: Whatever is permanent is seen to be unproduced, like space etc. But sound is produced - this is the negative method.

analyzed: sādhana ābhāsaḥ dūṣaṇa ābhāsaḥ ca uktaḥ
translated: The semblance of proof and the semblance of refutation have been stated.

analyzed: kim nāma pratyakṣam iti  pratyakṣam kalpanā apoḍham abhrāntam
translated: What is called perception?🔽Perception is free from conceptualization and non-erroneous.

analyzed: akṣam pratigatam āśritam yat vijñānam tat pratyakṣam
translated: That cognition which has gone to, i.e., is based on, the sense faculty is perception.

analyzed: pañca indriya āśritam jñānam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: cognition based on the five sense faculties.

original: atyādayaḥ krāntādyarthe dvitīyayeti samāsenābhidheyaliṅgaḥ pratyakṣaśabdaḥ siddhaḥ /
analyzed: ati ādayaḥ krānta ādi arthe dvitīyayā iti samāsena abhidheya liṅgaḥ pratyakṣa śabdaḥ siddhaḥ
translated: The word 'pratyakṣa' is established as having the gender of its object by the compound 'atyādyaḥ kṛntādyārthe dvitīyayā', meaning 'atyādi is in the sense of kṛntādi, in the second case'.

original: pratyakṣo 'vabodhaḥ pratyakṣā buddhiḥ pratyakṣaṃ jñānaṃ ceti yuktaṃ bhavati //
analyzed: pratyakṣaḥ vai bodhaḥ pratyakṣā buddhiḥ pratyakṣam jñānam ca iti yuktam bhavati
translated: It is proper to say 'pratyakṣa is understanding', 'pratyakṣa is cognition', and 'pratyakṣa is knowledge'.

original: cakṣuḥ śrotraṃ nāsikā jihvā kāyaśceti pañcendriyāṇi /
analyzed: cakṣuḥ śrotram nāsikā jihvā kāyaḥ ca iti pañca indriyāṇi
translated: The five sense faculties are the eye, ear, nose, tongue, and body.

original: tadāśritasya jñānasya pañca grāhyaviṣayā rūpaṃ śabdo gandho rasaḥ spraṣṭavyañceti pañcaiva prameyāṇi //
analyzed: tad āśritasya jñānasya pañca grāhya viṣayāḥ rūpam śabdaḥ gandhaḥ rasaḥ spraṣṭavyam ca iti pañca eva prameyāṇi
translated: The five objects of cognition of the cognition based on them are form, sound, smell, taste, and touch.

original: tacca pratyakṣaṃ nāmajātyādikalpanāpoḍhaṃ nirvikalpaṃ vā yadi punarabhrāntaṃ pramāṇamucyate pradarśitārthe 'visaṃvādāt /
analyzed: tat ca pratyakṣam nāma jāti ādi kalpanā apoḍham nirvikalpam vā yadi punar abhrāntam pramāṇam ucyate pradarśita arthe visaṃvādāt
translated: And that perception, which is free from conceptualization of name, universal, etc., is non-conceptual. If it is again called a means of valid knowledge because it is non-erroneous, due to non-contradiction in the object shown,

analyzed: tatra nāma vikalpaḥ devadattaḥ yam iti jñānam
translated: therein, the conceptualization of name is the cognition 'this is Devadatta'.

analyzed: jāti vikalpaḥ yam gauḥ iti jñānam
translated: The conceptualization of universal is the cognition 'this is a cow'.

analyzed: viśeṣya viśeṣaṇa vikalpaḥ nīlam utpalam iti
translated: The distinction between the qualified and the qualifier is like blue lotus.

analyzed: anyaḥ pi sa vikalpaḥ pratyakṣa ābhāsaḥ
translated: Another kind of conceptual cognition is a semblance of perception.

analyzed: vidyamāne rthe vibhramaḥ taimirikasya dvi candra jñānam
translated: A delusion about an existing object is like the cognition of two moons for one with an eye disease.

analyzed: śuktau rajata jñānam
translated: The cognition of silver in a shell.

original: ayaṃ sthāṇurvā puruṣo veti jñānaṃ ca /
analyzed: ayam sthāṇuḥ vā puruṣaḥ vā iti jñānam ca
translated: And the cognition Is this a post or a man?

analyzed: jñāna antaram api pratyakṣa ābhāsaḥ pradarśita artha a prāpaka tvāt
translated: Another kind of cognition is a semblance of perception because it does not lead to the attainment of the object that is indicated.

analyzed: tatra pratyakṣam trividham
translated: There, perception is of three kinds.

original: vyāvahārikamindriyajñānaṃ sarvacittacaittānāmātmasaṃvedanaṃ svasaṃvedanaṃ bhūtārthabhāvanāsphuṭaprakarṣaparyantajaṃ yogijñānaṃ ceti //
analyzed: vyāvahārikam indriya jñānam sarva citta caittānām ātma saṃvedanam sva saṃvedanam bhūta artha bhāvanā sphuṭa prakarṣa paryanta jam yogi jñānam ca iti
translated: Vyaavaharikam, indriya-jnanam, sarva-citta-caittanam, atma-vedanam, sva-vedanam, bhutatma-bhavana-sphuta-prakarsa-paryantajam, yogi-jnanam iti.

analyzed: tasya viṣayaḥ svalakṣaṇam
translated: Its object is the specific property.

analyzed: arthakriyā samartham sva lakṣaṇam
translated: The specific property is capable of effective action.

analyzed: na sāmānyam arthakriyā samartham
translated: The universal is not capable of effective action.

analyzed: tat eva ca pratyakṣam pramāṇam artha pratīti rūpa tvāt phalam api
translated: And that itself is perception, a means of valid knowledge, because it has the form of the cognition of an object, and it is also the result.

analyzed: tathātvena ca pramāṇa phalayoḥ na manāk api bhedaḥ
translated: And in that way, there is not the slightest difference between the means of valid knowledge and the result.

analyzed: dvividham anumānam sva artham para artham ca
translated: Inference is of two kinds: for one's own sake and for the sake of others.

original: tatra svārthaṃ tāvat pakṣadharmagrahaṇāt sādhyasādhanasambandhasmṛteḥ paścāt pratipatturarthasya yathāvadyā pratītistadeva svārthānumānam
analyzed: tatra svārtham tāvat pakṣa dharma grahaṇāt sādhya sādhana sambandha smṛteḥ paścāt pratipattuḥ arthasya yathāvat yā pratītiḥ tat eva svārtha anumānam
translated: Among them, first, one's own purpose is the cognition of the property of the subject, the recollection of the relation between the probandum and the probans, and then the correct understanding of the object by the cognizer. That itself is one's own purpose inference.

analyzed: pakṣa dharmaḥ tri prakāraḥ eva kāryam svabhāvaḥ nupalabdhiḥ ca
translated: The property of the subject is of three kinds only: effect, nature, and non-apprehension.

analyzed: kārya kāraṇa siddhau kāryam hetuḥ iti
translated: In the establishment of cause and effect, the effect is the reason.

original: yathā yatna dhūmaḥ tatra agniryathā mahānasādau /
analyzed: yathā dhūmaḥ tatra agniḥ yathā mahānasa ādau
translated: Just as where there is smoke, there is fire, like in a kitchen, etc.

analyzed: atra api dhūma sadbhāvāt iti
translated: Here also, because of the existence of smoke.

original: agnyabhāve dhūmābhāvo yathā sajale deśa iti atra tu dhūmāditi //
analyzed: agni abhāve dhūma abhāvaḥ yathā sa jale deśe iti atra tu dhūmāt iti
translated: In the absence of fire, there is no smoke, like in a place with water. But here, from smoke.

analyzed: svabhāvaḥ hetuḥ
translated: Nature is the reason.

analyzed: vṛkṣaḥ yam śiṃśapā tvāt pūrva vyavahāra āpanna śiṃśapā vat
translated: This is a tree because it is a shimshapa, like a shimshapa encountered in a previous transaction.

analyzed: vṛkṣa abhāve śiṃśapā abhāvaḥ yathā vṛkṣa rahite pradeśe
translated: In the absence of a tree, there is no shimshapa, like in a place devoid of trees.

original: iha punastena vyāpakena rūpeṇa vyāpyo hetuḥ //
analyzed: iha punar tena vyāpakena rūpeṇa vyāpyaḥ hetuḥ
translated: But here, the pervaded is the reason in the form of the pervader.

analyzed: anupalabdhi hetuḥ
translated: Non-apprehension is the reason.

analyzed: atra ghaṭaḥ na astu upalabdhi lakṣaṇa prāptasya anupalabdheḥ śaśaviṣāṇa ādi vat
translated: Here, the pot does not exist because of the non-apprehension of what is to be apprehended, like the horn of a rabbit.

analyzed: atra api yadā upalabdhi yogya anupalabdhau upalabdhi yogya abhāva vyāptiḥ niścīyate tadā ayam hetuḥ tad pratipādakaḥ bhavati
translated: Here also, when the pervasion of the absence of what is capable of being perceived by the non-perception of what is capable of being perceived is ascertained, then this reason becomes the expounder of that.

analyzed: kīdṛśāḥ anumāna ābhāsāḥ
translated: What are the fallacious inferences?

analyzed: pūrvavat śeṣavat sāmānyatodṛṣṭam ca para kalpitāni sarvāṇi anumānāni anumāna ābhāsāḥ
translated: All the inferences imagined by others, such as the a priori, the a posteriori, and the inference from analogy, are fallacious inferences.

analyzed: teṣām tādātmya tu utpatti lakṣaṇena pratibandha abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no relation in the form of identity or causality between them.

original: hetuphalasambandhe vyāpyavyāpakasambandhe ca siddhe sādhyasādhanasambandho bhavati nānyathā visaṃvādakatvāt //
analyzed: hetu phala sambandhe vyāpya vyāpaka sambandhe ca siddhe sādhya sādhana sambandhaḥ bhavati na anyathā visaṃvādaka tvāt
translated: The relation between the reason and the consequence is established only when there is a relation between the pervaded and the pervader, not otherwise, because it is not contradicted.

analyzed: yathā meghaḥ yam vṛṣṭimān dṛśyate
translated: For example, this cloud is seen to be accompanied by rain.

analyzed: gambhīra nirghoṣavat tvāt iti atra gambhīra ghoṣavataḥ meghāt vṛṣṭi anudbhava sambhavāt
translated: Because it has a deep rumbling sound. Here, it is possible that rain does not arise from a cloud with a deep rumbling sound.

analyzed: yathā upariṣṭāt vṛṣṭam nadī vṛddhi darśanāt iti
translated: For example, it is seen that the river rises due to rain above.

analyzed: nadī nirodhāt api nadī vṛddhi darśanāt
translated: Because it is seen that the river rises even when the river is obstructed.

analyzed: evam ime taṇḍulāḥ siddhāḥ eka pātra madhya varti tvāt dṛṣṭa taṇḍula vat
translated: In the same way, these rice grains are cooked, because they are seen in the same vessel as the cooked rice.

original: imāni phalāni pakvānyekaśākhāto jātatvādbhuktaphalavadityatra prāyeṇaivaṃ dṛṣṭe 'pi sādhyasādhanayorvisaṃvāda eva //
analyzed: imāni phalāni pakvāni eka śākhātaḥ jāta tvāt bhukta phala vat iti atra prāyeṇa evam dṛṣṭe sādhya sādhanayoḥ visaṃvādaḥ eva
translated: These fruits are ripe, because they are produced from one branch, like fruits that have been eaten. Although this is generally seen in this way, there is still a contradiction between the probandum and the probans.

original: yatpārthivaṃ tatsarvaṃ lohalekhyaṃ dṛśyate yathā vṛkṣādaya iti /
analyzed: yat pārthivam tat sarvam loha lekhyam dṛśyate yathā vṛkṣa ādayaḥ iti
translated: Whatever is earthy is all seen to be scratched by iron, like trees and so on.

analyzed: atra vajraḥ pi pārthivaḥ
translated: Here, even a diamond is earthy.

original: ye prāṇinaste sarve sakandharā yathoṣṭrādaya iti /
analyzed: ye prāṇinaḥ te sarve sa kandharāḥ yathā uṣṭra ādayaḥ iti
translated: Those creatures all have necks, like camels and so on.

analyzed: atra kulīraḥ pi prāṇī
translated: Here, even a chameleon is a creature.

analyzed: yat drava dravyam tat ārdram dṛśyate yathā jalam iti
translated: Whatever liquid substance is seen to be moist, like water.

analyzed: atra drava dravyam
translated: Here, even a juice is a liquid substance.

analyzed: evam anye pi anumāna ābhāsāḥ dṛśyante  iti paṇḍita pravara jitāri pāda kṛtaḥ hetutattvopadeśaḥ sampūrṇaḥ
translated: In this way, other fallacious inferences are also seen.🔽Thus, the teaching on the nature of logical reasons composed by the feet of Jitāri, the foremost of scholars, is complete.

original: bhāratīyopādhyāyena paṇḍitena kumārakalasena bhāṣāntarakārakeṇa bhikṣuṇā śākyaprabheṇa ca bhoṭabhāṣāyāṃ vipariṇamayya saṃśodhya ca vinyastaḥ
analyzed: bhāratīya upādhyāyena paṇḍitena kumārakalasena bhāṣā antara kārakeṇa bhikṣuṇā śākyaprabheṇa ca bhoṭa bhāṣāyām vipariṇamayya saṃśodhya ca vinyastaḥ
translated: It was translated and revised into the Tibetan language by the Indian preceptor and scholar Kumārakalaśa, and the monk Śākyaśrī, who translated and revised it from the foreign language.
